opinions.text:
OPINION OF THE COURT
Appellant challenges the propriety of the trial courtâ€™s determination that he violated probation imposed upon the Appellantâ€™s conviction for the offense of driving while license suspended. The affidavit of the Appellantâ€™s probation officer alleged violations of standard conditions of probation numbers 1, 2, 7 and 9, as well as a special condition of probation pertaining to a fine and court costs.
After reviewing the Record on Appeal and the appellate briefs filed in the case, this Court is of the opinion that the trial courtâ€™s revocation of the Appellantâ€™s probation is supported by competent, substantial evidence that the Appellant violated the special condition of probation and standard conditions 2 and 9. Therefore, the Appellantâ€™s Judgment and Sentence are AFFIRMED.
DATE OF DECISION OCTOBER 3, 1991.
The trial courtâ€™s determination that the Appellant violated standard condition 1 requiring that the Appellant procure the consent of his probation officer prior to changing his residence is erroneous, inasmuch as the Appellant had no control over his whereabouts while incarcerated.

attorneys: Eric R. Eide, Assistant Public Defender, for appellant.
Paula C. Coffman, Assistant State Attorney, for appellee.
casebody.head_matter:
JOHNSON v STATE OF FLORIDA
Case No. CJAP No. 89-91
Ninth Judicial Circuit, Orange County
October 3, 1991
APPEARANCES OF COUNSEL
Eric R. Eide, Assistant Public Defender, for appellant.
Paula C. Coffman, Assistant State Attorney, for appellee.
Before WALTER KOMANSKI, Circuit Judge.
